common_uses: Primary software switcher for multi-camera livestreams
Graphics, overlays, lower thirds, playback clips, and recording
NDI ingest from cameras, laptops, and graphics machines
failure_modes: vMix preview/program frozen or dropped frames
NDI inputs not appearing
No audio levels in vMix
Output not reaching streaming destination (YouTube, Vimeo, RMTP, etc.)
field_troubleshooting: Verify vMix is not in 'Pause' or 'Replay' mode by accident.
Check CPU and GPU load; close browsers and background apps if the system is pegged.
For missing NDI inputs, verify the camera or sender is on the same network/VLAN and NDI tools see it.
Confirm vMix output settings: correct streaming profile, bitrate, resolution, and target RTMP URL/key.
If program looks fine but stream is offline, test upstream by opening speedtest.net and checking upload speed.
Have techs note scene name, input names, and what changed just before failure (new source, new title, etc.).
field_notes: Document per-event: vMix version, scene/template used, number of inputs, and max CPU/GPU load.
If you change any virtual audio routing (VB-Audio, ASIO, etc.), record what was changed for the next tech.

common_uses: Base camera for single-cam and simple multi-cam streams
Locked-off shots for ceremonies, speakers, or commentators
failure_modes: No signal coming into capture device or switcher
Soft focus / out of focus subjects
Over- or under-exposed image in mixed lighting
field_troubleshooting: Confirm camera is powered (battery or AC), lens cap off, and HDMI/SDI fully seated.
Check output settings: ensure HDMI is enabled and not set to 'clean off' modes that change output unexpectedly.
For focus issues, switch to One-Shot AF on center point, focus on subject’s eye/chest, then lock focus if needed.
In high contrast rooms, start with full auto and then gently adjust exposure via iris and gain rather than shutter.
If image isn’t showing on vMix/ATEM, try a different cable and a different input to isolate cable vs camera vs device.
field_notes: At the end of shows, have techs note: gain level, shutter, and whether they were forced into high-gain/noisy modes.
If a specific G21 body behaves differently, tag it in notes so it can be serviced or reserved for lower-stakes shows.

common_uses: Primary cameras for multi-camera professional livestreams
NDI/SDI/HDMI feeds into vMix and ATEM switchers
failure_modes: Auto-focus hunting during low light or fast motion
No SDI/HDMI signal at the switcher/encoder
Color mismatch with other cameras on the show
field_troubleshooting: In low light, avoid full continuous AF; use One-Shot AF or Face Priority and reduce how often you half-press.
Check the output format (1080i vs 1080p, frame rate) matches switcher/project settings; mismatches cause 'No Signal'.
If picture is milky or noisy, verify internal ND filters and gain; techs should log what ND and gain they ended up on.
When matching cameras, start with Canon preset profiles and tweak white balance and saturation, not extreme custom curves.
field_notes: Technicians should record: project frame rate, output format, AF mode, ND/gain choices, and any AF failure scenarios.
If a body consistently loses AF under certain stage lighting, log details for future pre-show AF strategy.

common_uses: Field confidence monitors on cameras or director table
Program/preview reference when main multiview is far away
failure_modes: No image on monitor
Wrong aspect ratio or zoomed-in view
Color/brightness radically off from program feed
field_troubleshooting: Check HDMI/SDI cable is fully seated on both ends; swap cable if in doubt.
Verify the input source (HDMI/SDI) on the monitor matches the cable used.
When image looks crushed or stretched, reset aspect/zoom settings in monitor menu.
If the monitor looks wildly different from program, use it only as a framing reference and rely on the main program monitor for color.
field_notes: Log which monitors are best for focus peaking and which have weaker panels.
Note any unit where the power barrel is loose or intermittent.

common_uses: HDMI/SDI cross-conversion and scaling
Feeding old projectors or displays with odd resolutions
Cleanup between mismatched camera/switcher formats
failure_modes: No output signal while input is live
Wrong resolution/frame rate getting to downstream device
Confusion between IN/OUT ports and loop-through
field_troubleshooting: Confirm which port is input (SDI/HDMI) and that LEDs show lock.
Use the built-in LCD/menu to verify input format and set output format to what the downstream gear expects.
If downstream device won’t sync, try a more common format (1080p30 or 1080i59.94) and re-test.
Power-cycle the MD-HX and reseat SDI/HDMI if behavior looks inconsistent.
field_notes: Record any recurring problematic format combos (e.g., certain projectors hating 1080p60).
Note which shows required unusual scaling so future techs can reuse those settings.

common_uses: Splitting a single SDI program feed to multiple monitors/recorders
Feeding IMAG, lobby displays, and record decks simultaneously
failure_modes: Some outputs work while others are dead
Intermittent dropouts when all outputs are used
Downstream devices not locking to signal
field_troubleshooting: Verify the SDI source is clean by testing a single direct run first.
Check that total SDI cable length from source → splitter → destination stays within spec.
If only one output is needed, try a different output port to rule out a single bad jack.
If multiple far-runs cause issues, reduce how many distant loads you are driving from one splitter.
field_notes: Note any output jacks that behave flaky so they can be avoided.
Document typical cable runs (lengths/destinations) used on big shows.

common_uses: Small four-input HDMI switcher for simple streams
Backup or portable switcher for remote shows
failure_modes: No program output on HDMI or USB-C
Inputs not showing video even though cameras are on
Streaming direct from the ATEM fails while local recording works
field_troubleshooting: Confirm each input is sending 1080-compatible formats; the Mini Pro is picky about resolutions/frame rates.
Test each camera directly into a monitor to rule out camera/cable issues.
Check ATEM Software Control for correct program/preview routing and streaming profile.
If USB-C webcam output is missing, try a different cable and USB port on the computer.
field_notes: Record which cameras and frame rates paired well with the Mini Pro on each show.
Note any shows where the ATEM streaming profile had to be lowered for bandwidth reasons.

common_uses: Receiving ATEM program feeds over the internet
Sending video to remote venues or overflow rooms
failure_modes: No video even though ATEM is streaming
Frequent stutters or drops on receive side
IP/port configuration confusion
field_troubleshooting: Verify the Streaming Bridge has the correct IP and that the ATEM profile being used matches.
Check firewalls/NAT settings; ATEM must be able to reach the Bridge’s public-facing address.
If the link is unreliable, have techs test a lower bitrate profile or a different network path.
Log ISP, upload speed, and any VPN use when issues happen.
field_notes: Document working IP/port schemes used per venue for quick reuse.
Note specific ISPs or venues that gave trouble so future techs can plan redundancy.

common_uses: SDI/HDMI capture and playout into vMix or NLEs
High-quality I/O for Mac/PC workflows
failure_modes: Computer not seeing the device
No video in software despite signal present at SDI/HDMI
Audio not embedding/de-embedding correctly
field_troubleshooting: Confirm AJA drivers and control panel are installed and up to date.
Check input routing in AJA Control Panel matches the physical connection (SDI vs HDMI, channel selection).
Verify project resolution/frame rate in vMix/NLE matches the incoming signal.
Try a different Thunderbolt cable/port if the device disappears from the system.
field_notes: Record which driver/firmware versions are stable so future updates can be evaluated against that baseline.
Log any quirks with specific host laptops (e.g., certain USB-C/Thunderbolt ports).

common_uses: Primary bonded encoder for field livestreams
Streaming from venues without reliable wired internet
failure_modes: Unit will not go live or stays in 'connecting'
Severe buffering despite seemingly good cellular
RTMP destination errors
field_troubleshooting: Verify all modems/SIMs are active and have signal; disable any dead modems to avoid dragging the group down.
Check that Wi-Fi and Ethernet connections are either intentionally used or disabled—avoid a bad Wi-Fi pulling the group down.
Confirm RTMP URL/key exactly matches the destination settings (case-sensitive).
If venue upload is poor, lower bitrate and/or resolution and retry.
Have techs record upload tests (speedtest) before and after issues for post-event review.
field_notes: Document which carriers perform best at each venue.
Note any shows where Solo needed manual modem disable/enable so future techs can anticipate.

common_uses: Higher-end bonded streaming with more modems or 5G
Flagship encoder for premium events
failure_modes: Same as Solo plus advanced bonding misconfigurations
Battery/runtime issues under long events
field_troubleshooting: Treat initial checks like the Solo: carrier health, bonding state, RTMP settings.
Monitor battery runtime and log any unexpected drops or thermal throttling.
If a single carrier is weak, adjust weighting or temporarily remove it from bonding pool.
field_notes: Log per-venue carrier performance and bonding configs that worked best.
Record any firmware versions tied to stability problems.

common_uses: Primary or backup internet at rural/remote venues
Uplink for encoders like LiveU, vMix, or ATEM
failure_modes: Dish fails to connect or stays in 'searching'
Bandwidth dips below safe streaming thresholds
Mounting/location issues blocking view
field_troubleshooting: Set up with a clear view of the sky; avoid trees and tall buildings.
Allow enough warm-up time before show to confirm stable throughput.
Run speedtests and note sustained upload; adjust stream bitrate to leave 50% headroom.
If it keeps dropping, consider moving the dish, lowering bitrate, or giving LiveU more cellular weight.
field_notes: Record each venue’s Starlink performance and obstructions for future planning.
Note best mounting solutions used (tripod, rooftop, etc.).

common_uses: PoE switch for NDI cameras and networked gear
Core switch for show LAN
failure_modes: Some NDI/NDI-HX sources not appearing
Random dropouts on certain ports
PoE under-powering devices
field_troubleshooting: Make sure critical devices are connected to the switch, not daisy-chained through cheap unmanaged switches.
Check total PoE budget vs connected devices; unplug non-essential PoE loads if problems appear.
Verify all show devices are on the same VLAN/subnet.
Log which ports feed which devices on each show for quick tracing.
field_notes: Document per-show network diagrams and port usage.
Note any ports that show recurring issues so they can be tested or avoided.

common_uses: Portable show router for local Wi-Fi and DHCP
Management network for NDI/vMix
Guest or staff Wi-Fi at events
failure_modes: Clients dropping from Wi-Fi
NDI traffic getting choked by consumer router limits
IP conflicts with venue network
field_troubleshooting: Avoid putting heavy NDI traffic over Wi-Fi; keep NDI wired where possible.
Use a dedicated LAN with your own IP range; don’t bridge blindly into venue networks.
If router is overloaded, reduce client count or offload non-critical devices.
field_notes: Log SSID/password and IP range used per show.
Note any venue networks that caused conflicts so you can pre-plan static ranges next time.

common_uses: Fixed wireless or backup internet at certain venues
failure_modes: Low bandwidth or high latency
LAN conflicts with show router addressing
field_troubleshooting: Check signal strength and run speed tests before relying on it.
Avoid double-NAT headaches by deciding which device will be the main router.
If being used only as a modem, configure bridge-like behavior where possible.
field_notes: Record venues where this hub performs well vs poorly.
Note preferred internal IP map when combining with your own router.

common_uses: Backup internet or secondary WAN path for bonding
failure_modes: Poor signal inside venues
Carrier deprioritization at crowded events
field_troubleshooting: Place near windows/higher locations to improve signal.
Test throughput at show start and during peak crowd.
If bandwidth is weak, use as a secondary path, not primary.
field_notes: Log speed results by venue and time of day.
Note any throttling behaviors so they can be anticipated.

common_uses: Portable multichannel recorder for commentary, podcasts, and backup
Interface feeding cameras or switcher with mixed audio
failure_modes: No audio recorded despite meters moving
Incorrect input source or phantom power issues
Recorder not feeding camera/switcher correctly
field_troubleshooting: Confirm SD card is inserted, formatted, and there is record time available.
Double-check which inputs are armed and that phantom power is on only where required.
If sending audio to cameras/switchers, verify output level (line vs mic) matches destination.
Have techs slate or verbally label tracks at the top of recording for later post clarity.
field_notes: Record typical gain settings per mic model (e.g., BPHS1 commentary vs handhelds).
Note any specific channels or jacks that are flaky.

common_uses: Table-top podcasting and small panel recordings
Backup to main audio system
failure_modes: Guests recorded too quietly or clipping
Headphone mixes not set correctly
USB interface issues to computer
field_troubleshooting: Set conservative gain at setup and have each guest do a loudness check.
Check each headphone bus; ensure the right mix is assigned.
If using USB, confirm host computer sees P4 as an audio device and sample rate matches session.
field_notes: Log per-show gain and headphone preferences if recurring hosts/guests.
Note any quirks with specific DAWs or recording software.

common_uses: Compact digital mixer for small shows and commentary
Feeding main mix to encoders and in-room PA
failure_modes: No audio output to stream despite meters moving
Bluetooth/app connection issues
Routing confusion between main and aux mixes
field_troubleshooting: Check main LR routing and that the correct bus is feeding the encoder.
Verify physical outputs (XLR vs TRS) and cabling.
If app control fails, power-cycle the mixer and reconnect Bluetooth/Wi-Fi.
Document which inputs are used for which mics/instruments at line check.
field_notes: Capture snapshots/scenes used for recurring show formats.
Note any venues where gain staging or feedback were tricky.

common_uses: Budget mixer for simple events or backup audio
Basic mic + music mixing for local PA or stream
failure_modes: Unclear routing between main outputs and monitors
Bluetooth pairing confusion
No signal at main outs despite channel activity
field_troubleshooting: Check channel assignment (L/R, subgroups) and master faders.
Confirm the correct output jacks are feeding the encoder/amp.
Avoid relying on Bluetooth for mission-critical program audio when possible.
field_notes: Record typical fader positions and gain structure when used for similar shows.
Note any noisy channels or jacks for maintenance.

common_uses: Splitting one headphone feed to multiple listeners
Talent monitoring for commentary and podcasts
failure_modes: Listeners hearing different levels or nothing
Noisy or distorted output at high gain
field_troubleshooting: Ensure a strong, clean input level from the source before cranking HM-4 knobs.
Check each output with known good headphones and cable.
Avoid daisy-chaining too many headphone amps.
field_notes: Log which positions on the HM-4 are typically used (1–4) so flaky jacks can be flagged.
Record any notes on preferred headphone models for talent comfort.

common_uses: Commentator headsets for sports and live events
failure_modes: Low or thin vocal tone
Excessive room noise or plosives
Crackling cable near the connector
field_troubleshooting: Position the mic just off the corner of the mouth, not directly in front.
Roll a little low-cut on the mixer to tame rumble.
If crackling occurs when moving, check strain reliefs and swap cables where possible.
Have commentators do a quick loudness and pronunciation test pre-show.
field_notes: Record which headsets have known cable issues so they can be re-cabled or benched.
Note gain/EQ settings that give a good tone for typical commentators.

common_uses: Macro control for vMix, OBS, Companion, or other show tools
Quick triggers for graphics, overlays, and camera cuts
failure_modes: Buttons not triggering actions
Profile not loading on correct machine/user
USB connection drops mid-show
field_troubleshooting: Ensure Stream Deck software is running and correct profile is loaded.
Verify Companion or vMix shortcuts are correctly mapped.
Use direct USB connections, avoid unpowered hubs.
Have a backup method for mission-critical triggers (keyboard shortcuts, vMix web controller).
field_notes: Save and label per-show Stream Deck profiles so any tech can reload them.
Document which macros are essential vs nice-to-have for each show type.

common_uses: Single-camera HDMI capture into a laptop
Backup capture path when other I/O fails
failure_modes: Computer not seeing Camlink as a source
No video despite signal
Overheating in tight spaces
field_troubleshooting: Try a direct USB 3.0 port; avoid hubs and long extensions.
Confirm camera output format is supported (1080p, not weird resolutions).
If it disappears mid-show, try a quick unplug/replug and re-select device in software.
Keep the Camlink physically separated from heat sources where possible.
field_notes: Record which laptops and ports have been most stable.
Note any cameras/formats that don’t play nice with Camlink.

common_uses: On-camera monitor + ProRes recording
Backup recording for high-stakes shows
failure_modes: No input signal from camera
Drive not recognized
Overheating in hot venues
field_troubleshooting: Confirm HDMI cabling and camera output settings (no HDCP, correct resolution).
Check SSD is correctly formatted for Atomos.
Monitor temperature and use shade/airflow where possible.
Verify record is rolling and timecode is advancing before leaving camera unattended.
field_notes: Log SSD models and any compatibility quirks.
Record per-show whether Atomos footage was needed so techs see its value.

common_uses: Running vMix, graphics, or playback
NDI send/receive and control surfaces
failure_modes: Thermal throttling under heavy loads
USB/Thunderbolt instability with capture devices
Power issues when adapters are forgotten or loose
field_troubleshooting: Ensure high-performance power mode and plug into AC for shows.
Lift rear of laptop slightly for airflow; avoid soft surfaces.
Keep capture devices on short, robust cables and test all ports before show.
Always note when a laptop had to run at reduced settings (fewer inputs, lower resolution).
field_notes: Per laptop, log max stable load: number of inputs, typical CPU/GPU usage, and codecs.
Note any ports that are flaky or any specific capture devices that prefer specific ports.

common_uses: Camera to switcher/recorder connections
Laptop to monitor/projector
failure_modes: Intermittent signal drops or no signal at all
Issues at long distances or higher resolutions
field_troubleshooting: Always test with a known-good spare cable before blaming devices.
For long runs (25ft+), use quality cables and/or active/extender solutions.
Avoid tight bends and high-tension runs; re-route if signal drops when cable is moved.
field_notes: Have techs mark any suspect cables and pull them from rotation.
Log distances and resolutions used when HDMI behaves marginally.

common_uses: Long-run video between cameras, converters, and switchers
failure_modes: Sparkles, dropouts, or no signal on long runs
Failed connectors due to strain or repeated coiling
field_troubleshooting: Swap in a known-good cable of similar length to isolate failures.
Verify run length is appropriate for cable grade and resolution (1080p vs 4K).
Check for crushed or kinked sections, especially near connectors.
field_notes: Have techs log which SDI lengths were used on which cams per show.
Tag and retire any cable that fails even once during a show.

common_uses: NDI, Dante, control, and internet connectivity
failure_modes: Intermittent NDI drops or control loss
PoE devices resetting under load
field_troubleshooting: Test suspect cables with a network tester when possible.
Avoid kinking or running cables alongside power for long distances.
For PoE gear, ensure cables are not damaged and are appropriate category/quality.
field_notes: Log which runs carry PoE vs data-only.
Tag any cable that fails a test and pull from show stock.

common_uses: Balanced audio runs between mics, mixers, and recorders
Sometimes used as 3-pin DMX in a pinch
failure_modes: Hum, buzz, or intermittent audio
Broken latch or loose pins
field_troubleshooting: Swap cable first when audio cuts out or crackles.
Avoid using XLR for DMX on critical shows; if you must, clearly label it DMX.
Check for bent pins or loose strain reliefs.
field_notes: Track which cables are used with which mics to see patterns in failures.
Mark and retire problematic cables quickly.

hardware.model: Power Cords, Tri-taps, Power Strips, Starfish
common_uses: Providing safe, distributed AC power to gear racks and camera positions
failure_modes: Loose plugs causing intermittent power loss
Overloaded strips or daisy-chained power blocks
Trip hazards from poor cable management
field_troubleshooting: Ensure all connections are fully seated and strain-relieved.
Avoid daisy-chaining strips; distribute load across multiple circuits.
Tape or cover walkways, especially where power and signal meet.
Note any strips that feel hot or smell off and pull them from service.
field_notes: Record how power was distributed at each venue (which circuits, approximate loads).
Note any tripped breakers or hot strips so future shows can plan differently.

common_uses: Mounting monitors, cameras, and accessories to truss, railings, or stands
failure_modes: Slipping or sagging during show
Clamps not fully tightened or on unsuitable surfaces
field_troubleshooting: Always verify clamp is on solid structure, not decorative elements.
Double-check all knobs before leaving position.
If a rig keeps drifting, add a secondary safety (safety cable or second clamp).
field_notes: Have techs record any improvised rigging solutions that worked well (and safely) for future shows.
Retire clamps or arms that no longer hold reliably.
